question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned not only how to further analyze the writing of Nobel prize winners themselves, but also how to unpack the historical and social contexts behind them. By covering a new work of literature every week, we got a sense of the type of writing that earns this sort of recognition, in addition to an understanding of the breadth of form and topics that have been awarded the Nobel Prize.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading a book a week and analysis readings critically, it also helped with writing literary texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read cross-textually and consider themes that persisted across all texts. I learned how to place texts in their historical, political, social environments. I learned how to bring in philosophical ideologies when reading texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking, analytical writing, literary criticism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Critical Analysis of Literature: One of the most significant skills I developed in this course was the ability to critically analyze literary works. We learned to dissect complex texts, examining their themes, narrative structures, character development, and use of language. This involved not only understanding the surface-level content but also interpreting the deeper meanings and societal implications. 
Historical and Cultural Contextualization: The course enhanced my ability to place literary works within their historical and cultural contexts. This skill was crucial in understanding the significance of each author's work in their time and its lasting impact.
Diverse Perspectives and Empathetic Understanding: Engaging with a broad range of authors from different cultural backgrounds greatly enhanced my ability to appreciate diverse perspectives. This course encouraged an empathetic approach to literature, urging us to understand and respect viewpoints and experiences different from our own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think more analytically about a literary text. I improved my skills in close reading, synthesizing my thoughts, and identifying themes that run throughout a piece.

response_text: Creative thinking and critical analysis

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned so much. We learned a lot about history and philosophy, and I think our explorations of so many texts in such depth made me a better critical reader and writer.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Our discussions of Nobel Prize-winning literature let us view these works through the lens of the author's personal background, the communal context in which they lived, and the goal with which they wrote—and of course, touched on colonialism as a recurrent theme in all the novels, short stories, dramas, poetry, and essays! I thought that although it was primarily lecture-based, I still felt that I was engaged and interested in each topic covered.

response_text: Exposure to German culture, basic German language concepts, and expansion of German oral speaking skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the basic structures of German writing, speaking, listening, and reading. I've learned the nominative, accusative, and dative cases. I learned more about German culture such as it's food and cars.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Intro to German. I learned grammar, vocabulary and culture

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the basics of German grammar, sentence structure, and vocabulary.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course seemed to go very fast and it was hard to keep up sometimes, but if you just stick with it, it turns out okay. It was a bit difficult to connect with my professor and I had a difficult time understanding some things they thought we all understood. I like the practice for homework, but I wish there was more of it in class. Lots of speaking in class, which is good, but it gets repetitive, but that's probably the point.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The small seminar aspect of the class greatly improved my knowledge and understanding of the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the style of learning things in derdiedas and then having a lecture on them the next day, which provided great clarification. Also, the amount of homework was never too little but never too much, it was the right amount. She also did an excellent job of involving everyone consistently throughout the lecture.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Whole-class speaking practice, where we each ask and answer a prompt from each other and get feedback, was helpful.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: My teacher facilitated my learning by providing many opportunities for corrections both on homeworks and assignments, as well as speaking in German in class to help us get used to hearing lots of German and being able to start understanding.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was very intellectually stimulating because learning a new language is always like that. We needed more practice though, especially in the form that we did the test.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Constant interaction with the instructor and the students made the class very intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think it was a good level of stimulation. Learning a language is difficult, but Kasturi did a good job of balancing learning with enjoyment, which made it easier to learn. She always found creative ways to teach the content and tied in real-life applications.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Der die das is a platform that I enjoyed and made learning feel accessible.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating because it caused me to think in a different language. German is relatively different than English in terms of sentence structure and I found it very interesting.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Just stick with it - it gets fast after the first couple of weeks so don't fall behind.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Kasturi makes the course. She makes learning a new language fun and highly enjoyable and manages to break down the most complicated of concepts to something that everyone can understand. I hope to take more classes taught by Kasturi in the future but I know even if I do not that I will be more than adequately prepared at the next step in my German language learning experience.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Only take it if you're interested in learning German. If you're taking it because you think it'll be an easy class, then it's not worth it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If I were to take this class again, I would make sure to understand the homework assignments, as well as just practice speaking in German. Watch German TV, listen to German music, and really immerse yourself in the culture. That way, this class will be second nature. I really enjoyed this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about German grammar and pronunciation. I also learned about aspects of German culture and gained some conversational and speaking skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Speaking, writing, reading, and listening using German language.

response_text: I have developed my skills of German grammar, and also my understanding of German culture, such as Sunday culture, German friendship/relationship.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the German grammar, German culture, and German dialogue (engaging in and listening to conversations in German).

response_text: I learned how to have basic conversations in German, talk about the things that I like, and communicate feelings and perspectives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course allowed me to grow my knowledge of German culture and the world around me. It also allowed me to improve my writing and conversational skills while also improving my confidence in speaking a foreign language.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: as an intro level course I did not know much about german prior to taking this class so I think now I have a good base level understanding of easy german vocabulary, along with knowing how to speak and write this vocab.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to use listening comprehension to grow my knowledge of the language. I also learned how to work with others to grow my language-speaking skills through conversation. And I started to do weekly, routine reviews to keep everything I've learned fresh in my mind.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Frau Leonhardt was an amazing instructor. She was always understanding, willing to help/answer questions, and made sure to ask frequently if there were questions. She facilitated my engagement with the course by being amiable and encouraging us to be immersed in the culture and to learn to make the language our own. She especially put up with any strange side tangents I came up with or comments I had which I think was integral to my investment in the class and language as a whole. I loved how the German department gave ample opportunities to engage with the department and learn outside of class as well, including interacting with German speakers at different levels/in different classes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Leonhardt is incredibly engaging! From the first day of the lecture, I admittedly felt intimidated since she initially spoke in German, but hearing her lecture in German instead of English is helpful in the transition to higher-level German classes. Over time, I felt that her way of teaching by lecturing in German helped me retain more words and learn much faster than if she had taught primarily in English.Additionally, she is very understanding and compassionate! Beyond lectures, she is always a helping hand outside of class and has been very approachable during office hours. I have stayed on top of work throughout the semester, but there were times when I found I was struggling with extenuating circumstances, such as family and mental health, and she has always been incredibly supportive in working with me to make sure I succeed in this class. I can confidently say she strives to ensure every student in her class does well to prepare for higher German classes. I am truly thankful and honored to have had Leonhardt as my professor, and she inspired me to consider studying abroad as a potential plan in later semesters.Lastly, I enjoyed the curriculum of the course, namely self-grading homework assignments (based on how well we felt we performed), extra credit opportunities with Kulturpunkt, regrading opportunities (e.g. in-class writing assignments), and dropped grades (e.g. drop lowest quiz at end of the semester).  This put significantly less stress and anxiety on me academically and enabled me to enjoy learning German more. I hope they continue doing this in future semesters.

response_text: The German Department is the best! question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think creatively, to imagine while reading and make thematic connections between the works that I was introduced to during this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned to closely read fantasy literature, analyze common themes throughout fantasy fiction, and discuss how these themes are subverted or altered in modern fantasy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to view fantasy from historical epics as an insight into how societies were structured. How to discuss on topics that have conflicting scholarly reviews and find meaning in it. How to marry ancient and modern story telling and what it tells us about how society and pop culture has changed.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I learned how to analyze fantastical texts for their various elements, and appreciate them for their literary value. I learned how to analyze specific aspects of fantasy, like kings and kingdoms, bloodlines, and the roles of women. I learned how to write about fantasy and enhanced my critical writing skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained insight into how fantasy narratives have evolved over time, changing from fairly basic stories about invincible heroes to wel rounded stories with nw worlds of their own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically think about how overarching themes connect with different pieces of texts or films. I also worked on my writing skills since we had to write a paper (and received some good constructive feedback), along with improving my teamwork skills and communication thanks to discussing with a person around me every class and working in a group project.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped me to better analyze fantasy literature and media, specifically by looking at motifs in the genre, comparing works to other fantasy media, and seeing how works fit into and deviate from typical fantasy tropes and storylines.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to understand fantasy beyond what is being presented. There are a lot of underlining themes and motifs that I never considered when reading, watching, and interpreting such works. I gained a deeper knowledge for identifying these key themes and how characters operate. I think my critical skills of reading and writing improved as well as overall analysis of these fantastical works.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the construction of fantasy and it's associated themes, tropes, characteristics. I learned how to analyze movies and text. I learned that evaluating fantasy as "escapism" is a limited viewpoint.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: how to approach unfamiliar stories with antiquated language, how to think and write about fantasy, new exposure to different definitions and styles of fantasy

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I like the material we had to encounter. It was fantasy but we used it to compare it to everyday events. It was really interesting. I learned how personal experience affected how you interacted with each piece. I learned more about d&d from an academic standpoint. I learned how to compare and contrast each piece effectively.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the origins of many tropes I've taken for granted. I learned how to draw parallels between stories and modern societal problems and problems of the time. I furthered my understanding of fantasy as a medium for story telling and the tethers between myth, history, and story.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three things that I learned over this course were using my ability to think critically about media, understanding how people's perspectives influence genre, and how to write comparative essays.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How do evaluate beyond the surface-level descriptions of fantasy and dive into the meaning behind objects and characters
2. Comparing different stories in order to define common themes in fantasy 
3. How to analyze fantasy films

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I became much more open-minded through this course. I also developed my skills in fast-paced reading and analysis. Lastly, I learned a lot about how to relay information in an informative yet still highly engaging setting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the different tropes and themes that make up the fantasy genre and how cultural products deconstruct these things in modern times compared to years ago.I learned about Dungeons and Dragons, its history and development, how to play it in an actual campaign, and how it has influenced the mainstream cultural sphere of fantasy and been influenced in return.I learned how to analyze fantasy works on a deeper level, be it text, film, or photos, to find what about the fantasy reflects real-world ideals and how they sometimes mirror movements happening when fantasy cultural products are released.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We became well-versed in modern European short fiction and the genre's many renowned authors, such as Kafka, Svevo, Joyce, Woolf, Dostoevsky, Pirandello, Mann, Sartre, Camus, etc. We examined these works through the lens of five primary themes—animals, family and home, love, guilt, and the Holocaust—and determined how the stories can be categorized under one or more of these themes. We learned the distinction between modernism, post-modernism, existentialism, absurdism, communism, syndicalism, anarchism, and other ideologies in a literary context. We had the privilege of visiting the Rare Books library and picking works to analyze closely and the Nasher to look at the works of Chagall, Dali, and other relevant artists, as well as to do a compare/contrast essay on a short story and its film adaptation. These experiences allowed us to appreciate the important differences between different media: short vs. long-form fiction, final versions vs. galley proofs, film, and art. I also learned how to write a concise but effective paper, since our longest paper had a limit of three pages. Lastly, I learned how to appropriately analyze a short story by taking into consideration the plot, characters, author, and political/social implications.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to analyze literary works in relation to their  historical context. I learned about surrealism in literature and I also learned about the impact of stylistic features and literary devices (as similitudes or imagery) on the reader.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze writing styles, word choice, and how to access the rarebook library.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think my analytical writing improved. I gained a better understanding and general knowledge of European literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Got better at analytical writing, was exposed to writers of Europe's past, and got better at interpretive reading.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained substantial knowledge of authors, works, and movements that are significant to European literature.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love the way the course was structured, both the overarching structure of different themes for different groups of stories and the day-to-day structure of reading 1-5 short stories for class, coming to class to discuss in-depth, and then writing a short paper about a handful of these stories later on. I loved the unique opportunities the class had to offer, namely the Rare Books and Nasher visits and Francesca Magario guest lecture (I loved that lecture!). I loved the variety of papers: the close reading of a Kafka short short story, Rare Books object paper, animal research paper, and film and passage comparison essay. This is also the only humanities class in which I've had an exam, but I think it made sense to include it as an assessment because it forced me to stay on top of the readings (and come to class) and not just skim them. It meant I thoroughly read each story to learn the author's style and the story's influence. Professor Z is very insightful, prepared for class, engaging, and accommodating with deadlines, and she really shines when her students reciprocate an interest in the content. I was in a class with her last semester where the students were in general less engaged, which I think limited her teaching. This time around, most of the class came having done the readings with interesting takeaways/interpretations and ready to discuss, and this meant she could offer more as a professor as well. The professor and the students, in addition to the stories we read, made this class truly one of my favorites that I have taken at Duke.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course if you can! It was one of my favorite classes that I have taken at Duke. The readings are both thought-provoking and entertaining, as are the in-class discussions we had about them. By the end of the course, you'll be able to say that you're well-versed in modern European short fiction authors like Kafka, Joyce, Woolf, Dostoevsky, Mann, Sartre, Camus, etc. You get to do some cool out-of-class excursions too, like to the Rare Books library and the Nasher. The professor is very knowledgeable, effectively facilitates class discussions, and is very accommodating with deadlines. Plus the papers are very short (max 3 pages). There is one exam where you have to match 12 or so quotes to their author/work and write about the immediate context and significance of the quote, but it is very doable if you do all the readings and come to class consistently. I genuinely have no criticisms of this class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Henry worked more than most any of my professors here to engage the class in not only understanding the material, but applying it to itself and to modern society. Bringing in literature ranging from 400 CE to the 2020s showed the incredible depth of the subject topic and also her adaptation as a scholar to the various evolutions of Arthurian literature over time. She was an incredible instructor, providing extensive feedback on essays and assignments and establishing a solid foundation for the rest of my years of studying English here at Duke.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned not only how to further analyze the writing of Nobel prize winners themselves, but also how to unpack the historical and social contexts behind them. By covering a new work of literature every week, we got a sense of the type of writing that earns this sort of recognition, in addition to an understanding of the breadth of form and topics that have been awarded the Nobel Prize.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading a book a week and analysis readings critically, it also helped with writing literary texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read cross-textually and consider themes that persisted across all texts. I learned how to place texts in their historical, political, social environments. I learned how to bring in philosophical ideologies when reading texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking, analytical writing, literary criticism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Critical Analysis of Literature: One of the most significant skills I developed in this course was the ability to critically analyze literary works. We learned to dissect complex texts, examining their themes, narrative structures, character development, and use of language. This involved not only understanding the surface-level content but also interpreting the deeper meanings and societal implications. 
Historical and Cultural Contextualization: The course enhanced my ability to place literary works within their historical and cultural contexts. This skill was crucial in understanding the significance of each author's work in their time and its lasting impact.
Diverse Perspectives and Empathetic Understanding: Engaging with a broad range of authors from different cultural backgrounds greatly enhanced my ability to appreciate diverse perspectives. This course encouraged an empathetic approach to literature, urging us to understand and respect viewpoints and experiences different from our own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think more analytically about a literary text. I improved my skills in close reading, synthesizing my thoughts, and identifying themes that run throughout a piece.

response_text: Our discussions of Nobel Prize-winning literature let us view these works through the lens of the author's personal background, the communal context in which they lived, and the goal with which they wrote—and of course, touched on colonialism as a recurrent theme in all the novels, short stories, dramas, poetry, and essays! question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned not only how to further analyze the writing of Nobel prize winners themselves, but also how to unpack the historical and social contexts behind them. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Critical Analysis of Literature: One of the most significant skills I developed in this course was the ability to critically analyze literary works. We learned to dissect complex texts, examining their themes, narrative structures, character development, and use of language. This involved not only understanding the surface-level content but also interpreting the deeper meanings and societal implications. 
Historical and Cultural Contextualization: The course enhanced my ability to place literary works within their historical and cultural contexts. This skill was crucial in understanding the significance of each author's work in their time and its lasting impact.
Diverse Perspectives and Empathetic Understanding: Engaging with a broad range of authors from different cultural backgrounds greatly enhanced my ability to appreciate diverse perspectives. This course encouraged an empathetic approach to literature, urging us to understand and respect viewpoints and experiences different from our own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think more analytically about a literary text. I improved my skills in close reading, synthesizing my thoughts, and identifying themes that run throughout a piece.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned a lot about interdisciplinary thinking and being able to evaluate situations from multiple perspectives. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A key skill I developed was examining primary sources from German history and effectively analyzing them. In terms of content, I learned about the German political system, germany's role throughout and in the aftermath of WW2, and German culture.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I enjoyed how theme-heavy and modern-knowledge this course is packed with. We learned several topics about modern-day Germany spanning from early 20th century to today, specifically in the Holocaust, GDR/DDR, the evolution of Feminism, the German election and government system, and energy politics. It built upon topics from 203/204, but in a more complex manner and required you to use a higher level of German speaking in order to engage with these topics. You really learn and interact with these topics in German which can be quite challenging but very rewarding throughout this course. 
We also had a good portion of grammar. Some parts of it were review and other parts were new. It was a good mix and helped solidify parts of my speech that needed work.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The conflict between ideological loyalty and material harm prevention—whether in the regulation of AI-generated disinformation or in the defense of capitalist market structures—reveal the same pattern repeats: ideology-first positions prioritize abstract principles even when faced with clear evidence of harm, while material-first positions seek to address concrete damage, even at the cost of ideological purity. This essay will show how this underlying dynamic shapes both debates over AI regulation and the longstanding capitalism versus communism controversy.In the current debates surrounding AI regulation, especially around deepfake imagery and disinformation, the divide is sharp. Anti-regulation advocates adopt an ideology-first stance, prioritizing principles of free speech absolutism and market autonomy. Organizations like the Cato Institute frame any attempt to regulate AI content as a slippery slope to censorship or dangerous government overreach. Similarly, the narrative that "innovation must be free from interference" dismisses the material harms caused by AI disinformation — such as manipulated election outcomes, voter suppression, and the erosion of public trust. The underlying ideological commitment to liberty and free market operation remains firm even in the face of mounting evidence that AI technologies, left unchecked, can profoundly destabilize democratic institutions.Conversely, pro-regulation advocates adopt a material-first position, focusing not on preserving ideological purity, but on minimizing measurable harm. They prioritize policies like mandatory watermarking of AI-generated media, platform accountability for disinformation campaigns, and transparency requirements for algorithmic content distribution. Their arguments are grounded in concrete evidence: AI models have exacerbated biases in hiring, deepened misinformation flows, and enabled new forms of exploitation and surveillance. Rather than focusing on deontological arguments about abstract rights, material-first proponents insist that preventing real-world damage must take precedence, even if it entails some limitations on absolute free expression or market freedom.This structure mirrors the capitalism versus communism debate throughout the twentieth century. Capitalist apologetics frequently operated from an ideology-first perspective, framing free markets and competition as "natural" forces immune to political critique. Ideologies of meritocracy — that wealth and success reflect personal virtue — mystified systemic inequalities, obscuring the exploitation and structural violence embedded in global capitalism. Even as ecological collapse, labor precarity, and extreme wealth gaps became more visible, defenders of market ideology dismissed these harms as "externalities" rather than evidence of fundamental flaws. Their loyalty remained not to empirical outcomes but to the abstract sanctity of market competition.On the other side, critiques of capitalism — including socialist and communist thought — adopt a material-first approach. These critiques prioritize harm reduction: alleviating poverty, protecting ecological systems, ensuring workers' rights, and reducing systemic inequality. They are less concerned with preserving the ideological purity of economic "freedom" and more concerned with minimizing the tangible suffering produced by capitalist systems. Whether through labor protections, wealth redistribution, or environmental regulation, material-first critiques demand that abstract ideals yield when faced with material devastation.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: In the traditional model of ideological control, elites dominate mental production by distributing first-order ideological content: direct messages about what is true, good, or desirable. However, this is no longer the only — or even the primary — mechanism. In the contemporary world, not only does mental production distribute first-order ideology, but also the enforcement of second-order ideology additionally distributes first-order ideology. Seemingly neutral frameworks like "free speech," "anti-misinformation," and "anti-hate speech" are second-order ideologies that not only prescribe how the media should distribute first-order content but universalize first-order values through their enforcement. Thus, the public inherits first-order ideologies not only from the media itself but derive them from universal prescriptions of what kinds of communication are deemed legitimate.Consider "misinformation" enforcement. During the Cold War, elites not only flooded the media with anti-communist messages; they also framed sympathy toward communism itself as "misinformation" or "subversion." Thus, communism being bad was not only simply conveyed through the arguments the media made, but through ruling the discussion of alternatives as inherently illegitimate and a form of misinformation. In this context, "misinformation" as a second-order ideology was a direct extension of a first-order ideological battle: capitalism versus communism.In today's technocratic context, however, "misinformation" serves a different second-order function. The contemporary enforcement of "misinformation" on the surface seems to be a simple second-order filter for accuracy. However, such a filter spreads a universalist belief in objective truth — the idea that there exists a singular, recognizable reality that must be protected and disseminated for the sake of social cohesion and progress. Through this enforcement, public life becomes organized around a metaphysics of universal objectivity, where being properly informed is valued above all else.The antithesis of this is free speech absolutism. Media and education have long glorified individual liberty, often portraying censorship as synonymous with tyranny. The enforcement of free speech absolutism — treating any regulation of speech as dangerous — quietly installs this ideological lesson as a universal framework: that freedom is valued above all else, even at the expense of others' feelings, social cohesion, or truth itself. In this framework, we value our freedom over information integrity, emotional safety, and democratic stability, perpetuating the first-order libertarian ideal without openly stating it.Similarly, anti-hate speech policies reveal how second-order frameworks distribute first-order ideology. Modern pluralistic societies emphasize the protection of marginalized groups, and content celebrating diversity and inclusion is everywhere. The enforcement of "anti-hate" regulations carries this deep implication: that emotional harm and subjective feelings deserve institutional protection. Thus, anti-hate enforcement teaches that our feelings should be valued — that emotional safety is not merely a private concern, but a political and communicative standard that reshapes the public sphere.In each case, second-order enforcement distributes first-order ideology by naturalizing its assumptions about legitimacy, safety, harm, and truth. What appears as neutral procedural management — combating misinformation, protecting speech, ensuring emotional safety — is in fact the continuation of elite interests by other means. Thus, mental production is no longer simply about distributing beliefs; it is about embedding frameworks that structure the conditions of belief themselves. Today's ideological domination operates not only on the level of what we think, but even more profoundly on what kind of relationship to truth, harm, and freedom we are allowed to have.

I had already consumed some of the media (film and literature mainly) that we discussed in this course, but through our in-depth class discussions, I learned to see these and many new materials through alternative perspectives. It was particularly exciting to discuss the context of different works and ponder the potential implications these contexts could have on the overall meaning of literature, film, and art. Finally, this course helped me develop an understanding of and an appreciation for the interconnectedness of people and ideas. Throughout the course, we saw the connections and overlap between the authors, artists, filmmakers, and philosophers located in Berlin, Prague, and Vienna. It truly made me appreciate and ponder the ways in which information is spread. And, how inspiration is spread as well.

It also helped that Dr. Gellen is clearly very passionate about the subject which made me excited to learn more and ask questions in class. I thought there was a good balance between papers and presentations. Grading was fair. I also really liked how often we finished the entire assigned reading (either because Dr. Gellen chose shorter works or they were spread out over several class periods). I  think I got more out of the short stories/novellas in particular by reading the entire thing rather than just an excerpt from the story.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Overall, I found the learning environment of this course to be positive and engaging. I particularly enjoyed the days structured with multiple types of learning activities. For example: individual presentations, a small group exercise, lecture, and larger class discussion. I found the variety of modes of instruction kept each class session exciting and also allowed for students of all learning styles to engage with the materials in different ways. The class itself was also a positive space to participate in, as I found that a strong sense of community was fostered early in the semester through small group activities and lunch during class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was very discussion based and allowed for open conversations between the students and the instructor. We were able to discuss many different elements of the works that we were studying for the day and allowed for us to delve into topics we were interested in exploring more in.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: As I mentioned above, I think the presentations were very stimulating, because they also helped you develop and explore your own viewpoint about a lot of the works.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: - the readings, the films, the assignments (papers and presentations), the extremely flexible nature of class discussions allowed me to always learn something new in class that I didn't think about before!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I found the readings to be very challenging but also incredibly interesting and well integrated into the themes discussed in the course. I thought the reading assignments seemed carefully chosen to build on our understanding of German-Jewish culture and our abilities to understand more complicated texts as the course progressed. I loved how we also looked at poetry and film and the days where we looked at the early editions of the books at Rubenstein were so cool and fun! I knew almost nothing about this topic before taking this class and I am so glad that I took this class. I learned so much and genuinely enjoyed coming to class every day. I wouldn't have been able to appreciate a lot of the material without the support/guidance of this class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I found the course content itself to be incredibly stimulating. I came into this course with very minimal knowledge about Modern German-Jewish history, literature, and culture. This course immersed me completely in the thoughts and ideas of a time period that I had never studied before and taught me to look at works of art and literature through a different lens. Authors and historical figures I was already familiar with, such as Kafka and Freud, took on new significance following our course discussions, and that in itself was incredibly stimulating. I loved being able to learn more about these figures and their work, as well as hear the thoughts of Professor Gellen and my classmates.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is very manageable if you stay on top of your work. Also, don't be afraid to ask questions or engage, it is a very unjudgemental environment, and engaging will help your learning a lot.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it!!! Don't be afraid if you are not Jewish, have no history/literature background, etc. because neither did I, and it meant that I was even more impressed with how much I had learned! I think that it is not an easy course and definitely challenges your German, but by the end of the semester you will be shocked by how much you've improved, and how the class actually feels less difficult by the end. Professor Gellen is an amazing discussion leader and I always feel like our class ended too early!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly recommend this class to anyone who is studying German! I think it could be fairly stressful without a strong German background but Dr. Gellen is also so kind and supportive and passionate about teaching about Jewish culture. I would expect to put a lot of effort into this class but it is well worth it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly recommend this course to anyone interested in an in-depth, comprehensive look at a moment in German history and culture. This course is excellently structured so that a student grows to understand the developments of German-Jewish culture in three cities: Vienna, Prague, and Berlin. Through a journey of popular and more obscure works of art, literature, and cinema, you will develop an understanding of the major anxieties, joys, and dilemmas present within the thoughts, livelihoods, and innovations of the early 1900s German-Jewish culture.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The dialectic is never a move back but always forward and through -- that's something very important to keep in mind for my dissertation project.
Philosophy will always be very hard for me. I do feel a little better equipped to understand what the Frankfurt school is/does, but I'm still very much intimidated by its massive scope.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- This course over-delivered in terms of intellectual history; aside from familiarity with first-generation Frankfurt School thinkers, I now feel more comfortable embarking on studies of earlier German philosophy mainstays--namely Kant and Hegel. 
- The asking for questions and then incorporating answers into lecture was a pedagogical masterclass. Generally, the pedagogical decisions seemed well-reasoned in what seemed like a difficult classroom (various backgrounds and interests).
- I feel like my analytic rigor in reading philosophic text has been strengthened, in a strictly logical sense, a historicist sense, and on the level of the form of the argument.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

The reading load is manageable, though, and the professor knows just about anything and is deeply passionate about the subject and about seeking good rapport with students in and outside the classroom.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
This course offered a rich learning experience, allowing me to:1. Explore major German-language literary and cultural works from the 18th and 19th centuries. These texts provided a deeper understanding of the intellectual and cultural developments of the period.
2. Practice skills in literary close reading, developing the ability to analyze texts on both a structural and thematic level. This skill was especially valuable in understanding nuanced stylistic choices and their broader implications.
3. Learn about developments in German literary history, and how literary histories were written or developed over time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I expanded the foundational knowledge of literary texts in this period.
I got to know different topics/themes/perspectives to engage with this period.
I got to know how different texts can be juxtaposed together in a meaningful way through particular perspectives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Exposure to New Texts: I was introduced to a variety of new and engaging texts, which broadened my literary and cultural perspective.
Analytical Skills: The course helped me refine my ability to critically analyze texts and connect them to broader theoretical and cultural contexts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think  of different literary currents as overlapping rather than happening consecutively. I learned how to approach close readings always with the historical context in mind and to think of both the time in which it was written and the time in which it was set.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learnt how to refine my close reading when dealing with texts that precede the 20th century. How to reconstruct the historic and social contexts in which these texts emerge, is a hermeneutic undertaking that I feel more comfortable in now.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned much more about close reading, something I struggled with (and still do to some extent) at the beginning of my career here. I also learned so much about the history of German literature and the subtle ways in which various texts were connected by trends either political, ideological, theoretical, or simply relational in nature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course introduced for me the genre of literary history and offered ways to engage with the genre through presentations. The course encouraged diverse lenses from which to analyze texts, allowing those in the classroom to learn from each other. The course provided a canonical approach to German Studies, yet was sure to feature minoritized literature (i.e. women's literature), when it would be entirely possible to simply follow an all-male canon.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The learning environment was excellent, and Stefani Engelstein was an outstanding instructor. The two weekly class sessions were highly engaging and felt like they flew by. Several aspects of the course stood out:* The weekly discussion posts were an effective way to engage with the material before class, and I appreciated that the instructor not only read them all but also mentioned them during discussions.
* The class discussions were consistently stimulating, encouraging different perspectives and critical thinking about the texts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor facilitated the communication/discussion among grad students. The instructor also gave interesting input from various perspectives. The instructor also used the board sometimes, which has been inspiring.

response_text: The class environment was very friendly and welcoming, which made it a comfortable space for learning and collaboration. Stefani's patience as an instructor stood out—her approachability and willingness to listen fostered open discussions and encouraged participation. For future years, I would recommend keeping this supportive and inclusive atmosphere, as it greatly facilitates learning and engagement.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
Having already read or taught some of the works discussed in class occasionally made the material feel repetitive. However, the instructor's ability to introduce new insights and perspectives kept the class engaging. Their encouragement of intellectual curiosity and critical engagement made even familiar texts feel fresh.
I also really enjoyed the two introductions to literary histories published in the 21st century that we read and discussed in the first class session. They offered fascinating insights into evolving methodologies and frameworks for understanding literature. I would love to explore more new or innovative approaches to writing literary histories, as this aspect of the course sparked my curiosity about how we narrate and structure the development of literary traditions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a good chunk of history in the post-war 20th century in Germany, covering aspects of Cultural Studies and sociology as well as important work and ideas by writers, poets, filmmakers, thinkers and scholars in this German Studies sub-discipline which I have always wished for an introductory course in. I learned how to think about texts and films that are sometimes in need of engagement because of their obscurity, profane nature or marginal positionality from a part of Germany's and Turkey's culture which I hitherto only knew from popular cultural production and interpersonal relationships.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Reisoglu has not only worked on many of the authors and filmmakers that he presented in this course, but he also comes to the course with an inherent knowledge of both Turkish and German cultures which adds an element to this course that I don't feel any other professor in the German Department could supply. If possible, I would have only him teach this course since he is also versed in the Turkish language and can convey aspects of the material covered in their original language that non-Turkish speakers may miss.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
This course was very enriching and allowed me to develop several important skills and insights: 
1) Exploration of Austrian Postwar Literature and Film: I gained a deep understanding of four major Austrian writers and filmmakers—Thomas Bernhard, Elfriede Jelinek, Michael Haneke, and Ulrich Seidl—whose works are foundational to postwar cultural and literary criticism in Austria.
2) Close Reading and Film Analysis: I improved my ability to engage in close reading and film analysis, emphasizing how to critically unpack texts and visual narratives in relation to broader social and cultural contexts.
3) Understanding Representations of Violence: I explored how graphic depictions of violence can serve as tools for education and enlightenment, pushing myself to remain open-minded about the purpose and impact of such representations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained exposure to a variety of Austrian films that I might not have encountered otherwise, broadening my understanding of Austrian film culture and its unique themes.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was highly interested in breaking down the notion of a Eurocentric Humanistic ideal due to the nature of the course design, i.e. transgressive thinkers. However, I learnt that often in academia, one has to bite the bullet and decide what battles to fight. As such I learnt to disengage from arguments that did not give me back fruitful ideas and were unproductive to thinking critically about the issues the artists' work that was the primary material in the course was trying to do. The actual work was often buried in the discussions about the artists themselves and the participants were not asked to refrain from make universal statements about the literary or film-studies based values expressed in the works. I learnt that when the discussion becomes performative, I must quietly save my labor for when I have the intellectual and emotional energy. I enjoyed quite a few of the readings, both primary and secondary, but found that the discussions were often overshadowed by manspreading in the workplace, an issue often unaddressed in the graduate seminar, a workspace often disguised as solely a classroom. Lastly, and on a positive note, I learnt how to identify textual evidence to dialectically decipher the place a given text occupies in the literary history as visible from the contemporary moment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learnt how to theorize my interpretation of a text based on a close reading instead of using theoretical lenses.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The overall learning environment was positive, and the course structure effectively supported my learning:* Student-Led Discussions: I appreciated the collaborative approach, as students leading parts of the discussion fostered engagement and new perspectives.
* Weekly Discussion Posts: Writing weekly posts allowed me to engage deeply with the materials, and I appreciated that the instructor thoughtfully read and provided feedback on all posts.
* Instructor Engagement: The instructor created an encouraging atmosphere for intellectual exploration.However, I think the discussions could benefit from integrating the weekly posts more directly into the class conversations.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment, I appreciated the instructor's openness and flexibility, which created a welcoming space for discussion. The weekly Canvas responses were particularly effective in fostering engagement and reflection, and I think this component should be kept for future classes. However, I would suggest incorporating more structured guidance from the instructor, as well as adding theoretical background and close readings to provide a stronger foundation for analyzing the films. These additions would enhance the learning experience by balancing discussion with deeper context and analysis.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professsor-instructor was highly amenable to being flexible about the primary textual materials under study in this class, especially with regard to the sensitivity of some participants and an incident that left many shook beyond performative solidarity with a participant new to the program. Moreover, the professor-instructor was kind about my own medical condition related to psychiatric health and did not hold it against me when I had to retreat from energetic participation into passive note-taking mode. I did not feel pressure to partake in any opinion-based consensus creation when the loudest members of the seminar were doing their usual think-out-loud discussions. I think the best part of this course was the discussion posts where the value-systems of each participants may be seen through close analysis of their writing styles and philosophical standpoints.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The course was intellectually engaging, but there is room for improvement in the selection of secondary readings: Some texts were excellent (I particularly enjoyed the Rita Felski reading), but others were less effective due to unclear writing or arguments (e.g., Ahmed, Berlant, Nelson). question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

Incorporating close readings of the texts, deeper engagement with key concepts, and connecting these ideas more explicitly to the films would have enhanced the intellectual depth. Additionally, balancing open discussions with structured input from the instructor could make the class more engaging and thought-provoking. One area for improvement would be including more trigger warnings and regularly checking in on students' mental health, as the nature of the films often addressed challenging and sensitive topics.

response_text: If the women were encouraged to speak more by asking the men to pipe down sometimes. I would have loved to see more decolonial thought on humanism as an exclusionary method to control humans and their poetic abilities as a member of the planet on a continuum with other forms of life and the material world that sustains them, rather than the notion of humans as elevated beings in control over the material reality upon which they are parasitic. far from being nihilistic, this poetic idea of a human as creative and trangressive rather than ascriptive and normative could have been the impetus for more stimulating and self-degrandizing set of discussions rather than 'redemption' as the limit of thought in the secularized versions of a Euro-Christian humanism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Wow. Learned a lot. We started with a pretty fundamental overview of the history behind the philosophy of mind. We started with Descartes, the father of modern philosophy, and moved on from there. Our book, Minds and Computers, concluded with computational theory of mind, which argues that if humans are machines, the brain is basically the hardware and the mind is the software. However, Searle showed us that computationalism can't answer intentionality (formal programs can't constitute understanding), so we have tried to find other theories that may work to explain the mind. Between Heidegger, Wittgenstein, Brentano, Dennet, Hagel, we have come to realize the importance of subjective experience in the world. So far, I really like the embodied mind theory and its appeal to naturalism.

I learned how AI works, simple things such as Siri or google AI works. I also learned a variety of philosophical theories of mind which were really interesting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The first thing I learned in this class was that I become more adept to learning from other peoples' perspectives and opinions. This class allowed me to collaborate with others through thought—meaning I was able to learn about a film or novel by hearing my classmates other perspectives, and I thoroughly enjoyed this. 
The second thing I learned was insight into the creative process behind horror. I learned about directors and authors motivations, and how horror literature and videography is created. 
The third thing I would like to mention that I learned is the foundation of horror, and how a lot of modern day films / contemporary fiction stem from gothic horror of the 18th century.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We became well-versed in modern European short fiction and the genre's many renowned authors, such as Kafka, Svevo, Joyce, Woolf, Dostoevsky, Pirandello, Mann, Sartre, Camus, etc. We examined these works through the lens of five primary themes—animals, family and home, love, guilt, and the Holocaust—and determined how the stories can be categorized under one or more of these themes. We learned the distinction between modernism, post-modernism, existentialism, absurdism, communism, syndicalism, anarchism, and other ideologies in a literary context. We had the privilege of visiting the Rare Books library and picking works to analyze closely and the Nasher to look at the works of Chagall, Dali, and other relevant artists, as well as to do a compare/contrast essay on a short story and its film adaptation. These experiences allowed us to appreciate the important differences between different media: short vs. long-form fiction, final versions vs. galley proofs, film, and art. I also learned how to write a concise but effective paper, since our longest paper had a limit of three pages. Lastly, I learned how to appropriately analyze a short story by taking into consideration the plot, characters, author, and political/social implications.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to analyze literary works in relation to their  historical context. I learned about surrealism in literature and I also learned about the impact of stylistic features and literary devices (as similitudes or imagery) on the reader.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze writing styles, word choice, and how to access the rarebook library.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love the way the course was structured, both the overarching structure of different themes for different groups of stories and the day-to-day structure of reading 1-5 short stories for class, coming to class to discuss in-depth, and then writing a short paper about a handful of these stories later on. I loved the unique opportunities the class had to offer, namely the Rare Books and Nasher visits and Francesca Magario guest lecture (I loved that lecture!). I loved the variety of papers: the close reading of a Kafka short short story, Rare Books object paper, animal research paper, and film and passage comparison essay. This is also the only humanities class in which I've had an exam, but I think it made sense to include it as an assessment because it forced me to stay on top of the readings (and come to class) and not just skim them. It meant I thoroughly read each story to learn the author's style and the story's influence. Professor Z is very insightful, prepared for class, engaging, and accommodating with deadlines, and she really shines when her students reciprocate an interest in the content. I was in a class with her last semester where the students were in general less engaged, which I think limited her teaching. This time around, most of the class came having done the readings with interesting takeaways/interpretations and ready to discuss, and this meant she could offer more as a professor as well. The professor and the students, in addition to the stories we read, made this class truly one of my favorites that I have taken at Duke.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course if you can! It was one of my favorite classes that I have taken at Duke. The readings are both thought-provoking and entertaining, as are the in-class discussions we had about them. By the end of the course, you'll be able to say that you're well-versed in modern European short fiction authors like Kafka, Joyce, Woolf, Dostoevsky, Mann, Sartre, Camus, etc. You get to do some cool out-of-class excursions too, like to the Rare Books library and the Nasher. The professor is very knowledgeable, effectively facilitates class discussions, and is very accommodating with deadlines. Plus the papers are very short (max 3 pages). There is one exam where you have to match 12 or so quotes to their author/work and write about the immediate context and significance of the quote, but it is very doable if you do all the readings and come to class consistently. I genuinely have no criticisms of this class.
